trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: “One patient dropped out after 2 weeks due to non-compliance” “Two patients developed significant medical illnesses ... unrelated to study treatment”, “By prior design, treatment for the first 8 patients was terminated after 8 weeks.”.
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "Both rater and patient were blind to the patient's drug assignment". No further details.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: Baseline AIMS scores were somewhat higher in the vitamin E group than in the placebo group, however, this difference was not statistically significant. Small sample size.

outcomeList.outcomeName: Tardive dyskinesia: 1. Not improved to a clinically important extent

trialList.performanceBiasJudgement: "Both rater and patient were blind to the patient's drug assignment". No further details.
trialList.references: Adler LA, Edson R, Lavori P, Peselow E, Duncan E, Rosenthal M, et al
Long-term treatment effects of vitamin E for tardive dyskinesia
Adler LA, Peselow E, Angrist B, Duncan E, Lee M, Rosenthal M, et al
Vitamin E in tardive dyskinesia: effects of longer term treatment
Proceedings of the 31st Annual Meeting of the American College of Neuropsychopharmacology; 1992 Dec 14-18; San Juan, Puerto Rico
Adler LA, Peselow E, Duncan E, Rosenthal M, Angrist B
Vitamin E in tardive dyskinesia: time course of effect after placebo substitution
Adler LA, Peselow E, Rotrosen J, Duncan E, Lee M, Rosenthal M, et al
Vitamin E treatment of tardive dyskinesia
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: All expected outcomes have been reported but there is no study protocol to confirm that all planned outcomes were reported.
trialList.selectionBiasAllocationConcealmentJudgem: "We used a randomization of 3:2 (vitamin E to placebo) to maximize the number of patients receiving active treatment while maintaining the blind". No further details.
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "Patients were randomly assigned to treatment with Vitamin E, 400IU, or one matching placebo capsule, by mouth, b.i.d." No further details.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: “Of the 51 subjects who did not complete 1 year, most changed their minds about participating (n=18), moved too far away from a site to continue in the study (n=11), or were classified as “whereabouts unknown” (n=8)”. “Per protocol, we analyzed the data according to the intention- to-treat principle.”.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: No significant differences between groups' baseline characteristics. Small sample size.

outcomeList.outcomeName: Tardive dyskinesia: 1. Not improved to a clinically important extent

trialList.references: Adler LA, Rotrosen J, Edson R, Lavori P, Lohr J, Hitzemann R, et al
Vitamin E treatment for tardive dyskinesia
Adler LA, Rotrosen J, Lavori P, Edson R
Vitamin E treatment of TD: development of a VA cooperative study
Vitamin E is ineffective in treatment of late dyskinesias
Vitamin E unwirksam in der Behandlung von Spatdyskinesien (TD)

Reliability of an instrumental assessment of tardive dyskinesia: results from VA Cooperative Study #394
Edson R, Lavori P, Tracy K, Adler LA, Rotrosen J
Interrater reliability issues in multicentric trials, part II: statistical procedures used in Department of Veterans Affairs Cooperative Study #394
Whither vitamin E and tardive dyskinesia?
Tracy K, Adler LA, Rotrosen J, Edson R, Lavori P
Interrater reliability issues in multicentric trials, part I: theoretical concepts and operational procedures used in Department of Veterans Affairs Cooperative Study 394
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: All expected outcomes have been reported but there is no study protocol to confirm that all planned outcomes were reported.
trialList.selectionBiasAllocationConcealmentJudgem: Allocation with "biased coin" method, stratified by site, age, and baseline TD.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: The study results seem to include all participants and there seem to be no dropouts from the study.
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "Both, the investigators and raters were blind to the nature of therapy · active drug or placebo till the completion of analysis.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: There was no significant difference in the demographic profile of the two groups. Small sample size.
trialList.performanceBiasJudgement: "double blind manner to receive either one capsule of 600 mg vitamin E or an identical placebo".
trialList.references: Akhtar S, Jajor TR, Kumar S
Vitamin E in the treatment of tardive dyskinesia
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: All expected outcomes have been reported but there is no study protocol to confirm that all planned outcomes were reported.
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "The patients were then randomly assigned". Details not reported.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: "One patient who was taking vitamin E stopped treatment after 2 weeks because of diarrhea, leaving five patients taking placebo and six vitamin E".
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "Each patient was rated blindly by one of us (L.M.D.) before and after treatment using the Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS)". Blinding details not reported.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: No statistically significant differences in AIMS baseline scores between groups. Very small sample size.
trialList.references: Dabiri LM, Pasta D, Darby JK, Mosbacher D
Effectiveness of vitamin E for treatment of long-term tardive dyskinesia
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: All expected outcomes have been reported but there is no study protocol to confirm that all planned outcomes were reported.
trialList.selectionBiasAllocationConcealmentJudgem: "patients were randomly divided into treatment and placebo groups by a non-clinical staff member".

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: The study results seem to include all participants and there seem to be no dropouts from the study.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: Baseline characteristics not reported. Very small sample size.
trialList.references: Dorevitch A, Lerner V, Shalfman M, Kalian M
Lack of effect of vitamin E on serum creatine phosphokinase in patients with long-term tardive dyskinesia
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: TD symptoms (AIMS) were assessed but not reported.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: "Two patients did not complete the study. Both patients were from the placebo phase of the placebo-vitamin E sequence group. One died while choking on food and the second as the result of a traffic accident".
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "Two senior psychiatrists served as blinded raters".
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: Baseline characteristics not reported.Small sample size.
trialList.references: Dorevitch A, Kalian M, Shlafman M, Lerner V
Treatment of long-term tardive dyskinesia with vitamin E
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: “Addition of vitamin E or placebo did not adversely affect patient mental status as measured by brief psychiatric rating scale (BPRS).“ BPRS data not fully reported.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: Not ITT analysis: "Eighteen patients who demonstrated high blood levels of vitamin E were included in the data analysis", 3 patients were excluded from the analysis.
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "All raters were blind to treatment with either placebo or vitamin E. ".
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: Baseline characteristics not reported. Very small sample size.
trialList.references: Egan MF, Hyde TM, Albers GW, Elkashef A, Alexander RC, Reeve A, et al
Treatment of tardive dyskinesia with vitamin E
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: Data for mental state (PSAS and NSAS) not reported.
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "Patients were assigned randomly" Details not reported.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: 2/5 subjects in the placebo group while none in the vitamin E group dropped out: "Two patients did not complete the study, one because of noncompliance and the other experienced substantial side effects (nausea) while taking placebo".
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "The subjects were evaluated biweekly by a blind trained rater using the AIMS and the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS)" Details of blinding not reported.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: The baseline severity of tardive dyskinesia was closely matched in the two groups. Very small sample size.

outcomeList.outcomeName: Tardive dyskinesia: 1. Not improved to a clinically important extent

trialList.references: Elkashef AM, Ruskin PE, Bacher N, Barret D
Vitamin E in the treatment of tardive dyskinesia
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: AIMS data partially reported and BPRS evaluated but not reported.
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "The subjects were then assigned in a random, double-blind manner...", no further details.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: Twelve subjects completed the trial. One patient died of unrelated medical illness, one contracted bacillary dysentery and was dropped from the trial, and one had poor compliance and refused to continue medication. It was not reported which groups these participants were allocated to.
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "Subjects were evaluated weekly with the AIMS...and Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale..., respectively, by two independent blind raters at the initial stabilization period,and the last 2 weeks of each test period".
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: Baseline characteristics not reported. Very small sample size.

outcomeList.outcomeName: Tardive dyskinesia: 1. Not improved to a clinically important extent

trialList.references: Lam LCW, Chiu HFK, Hung SF
Vitamin E in the treatment of tardive dyskinesia: a replication study
Journal of Nervous and Mental Diseases
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: TD symptoms data not reported as mean (SD); BPRS data not reported per period. Adverse effects not reported per group.
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "Subjects were then selected randomly". No further details.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: Dropout rate of 36% (20 of 55 patients) but not reported per study group "2 developed manic symptoms necessitating medical changes, and 18 were non-compliant with either the vitamin E or the psychotropic medication. These 20 patients, who did not differ significantly from the remaining 35 patients in terms of age, gender, or diagnosis, were dropped from the study".
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: Insufficient information to make a judgement.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: There were no significant differences in baseline characteristics between the two study groups. Small sample size.
trialList.performanceBiasJudgement: "Patients were randomly assigned to receive either active vitamin E or sesame oil placebo gel caps, which were indistinguishable from the active gel caps."
trialList.references: A double-blind placebo-controlled study of vitamin E treatment of tardive dyskinesia
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: Adverse Effects: extrapyramidal side effects (Parkinsonism) data not reported.
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "Patients were randomly assigned to receive either active vitamin E or sesame oil placebo gelcaps."

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: 40% drop-out (12/20 subjects completed the study): 6/11 subjects in the intervention and 2/9 subjects in the control group did not complete the trial. By the fourth month, there were 12 patients left in the trial, five in the treatment group and seven in the control group. Patients excluded at this stage included those whose dose of antipsychotic medication was changed.
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: Rater initially blind. However, after one month, the rater performed statistical tests and hence blindness was not maintained.
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: Mean AIMS scores and age were similar between groups at baseline. Very small sample size.

outcomeList.outcomeName: Tardive dyskinesia: 1. Not improved to a clinically important extent

trialList.performanceBiasJudgement: As an active group was compared to treatment as usual, the study could not be double blinded.The only person blinded seems to have been the doctor "...the dose increased by another doctor not involved in the ratings and who, therefore, was blind as to whether or not the patient was receiving a-tocopherol for the first month of the trial".
trialList.references: Vitamin E in the treatment of tardive dyskinesia: a preliminary study over seven months at different doses
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: All expected outcomes have been reported but there is no study protocol to confirm that all planned outcomes were reported.
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "...the patients were randomly divided into two groups using... a computer statistic programme."

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: 13 patients initially randomised to vitamin E: two left before the end of the study (1 died and the other withdrew); 10 patients initially randomised to placebo: two left before the end of the study (1 died and the other had his treatment modified).
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: Baseline characteristics similar between study groups. Very small sample size; cross-over design.

outcomeList.outcomeName: Tardive dyskinesia: 1. Not improved to a clinically important extent

trialList.references: Schmidt M, Meister P, Baumann P
Treatment of tardive dyskinesias with vitamin E
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: All expected outcomes have been reported but there is no study protocol to confirm that all planned outcomes were reported.

trialList.attritionBiasJudgement: "Forty-one inpatients with TD completed a double- blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study of vitamin E. Twenty- two of the patients were randomly assigned to receive a fixed dose of 1200 IU/d vitamin E, and 19 were assigned to a placebo". "Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either capsulized vitamin E (n=22) or identically capsulized placebo (n=19)". All randomised subjects seem to have completed the study.
trialList.detectionBiasJudgement: "TD was evaluated in all patients using the Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) at baseline, 6 and 12 weeks of treatment by the same trained investigator (DCC) who was blind to the patient's medication status. The patient's psychopathology was rated at baseline and at posttreatment using the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), 18 which was performed by 2 trained psychiatrists who were blinded scoring the PANSS."
trialList.otherBiasJudgement: "No significant differences in demographic data were observed between vitamin E and placebo groups".
trialList.performanceBiasJudgement: "either capsulized vitamin E (n=22) or identically capsulized placebo (n=19) using a double-blind fashion."
trialList.references: Zhang XY, Zhou DF, Cao LY, Xu CQ, Chen da C, Wu GY
The effect of vitamin E treatment on tardive dyskinesia and blood superoxide dismutase: a double-blind placebo-controlled trial
trialList.reportingBiasJudgement: Outcome data was not reported for mental symptoms (PANSS).
trialList.selectionBiasRandomSequenceJudgement: "Eligible patients were randomly assigned" no further details.
